Syria's trial over Alawite killings marks a break with the al-Assad era
subhead: Members of the security forces belonging to Syria's new authorities and supporters of former dictator Bashar al-Assad appeared in court in Aleppo for massacres that left 1,400 dead on the Syrian coast in March. This public trial is intended to demonstrate transitional president Ahmed al-Sharaa's commitment to the rule of law.

title: European Commission launches digital regulation simplification
subhead: Under pressure from Berlin, Washington and major tech companies, the European Commission has proposed delaying certain provisions of its artificial intelligence regulations and making data processing by AI developers simpler.

title: Early Greek repayment gives France surprise budget boost
subhead: Athens' €1.1 billion payment to Paris was a welcome relief during a period of severe budgetary constraints. In the early 2010s, France had come to Greece's rescue.

title: Nicolas Guillou, French ICC judge sanctioned by the US: 'You are effectively blacklisted by much of the world's banking system'
subhead: Six judges and three prosecutors at the International Criminal Court have been sanctioned by the Trump administration. In an interview with Le Monde, Guillou discusses the impact of these measures on his work and daily life.

'No one ever called us': Retired French police officer stunned to learn of daughter's death online, three months after burial
subhead: Jean Forest discovered this summer that his daughter Marjolaine, a university scholar, had been buried in the spring. He investigated why his family was not informed and denounces the administrative and social indifference he encountered.

title: 'Worthy of Game of Thrones': The EU Commission's battle for control of diplomacy
subhead: The president of the institution, Ursula von der Leyen, has been consolidating more and more powers, to the detriment of the historic diplomatic service led by Estonian Kaja Kallas, who now appears increasingly isolated.

title: Le Pen stand-in Bardella's presidential bid takes shape
subhead: Marine Le Pen said on Wednesday she would back Jordan Bardella, the president of her party, if her sentence banning her from elections is upheld at her appeal trial this spring.
